nexttext:
where $\mu_{B}$ is Bohr magneton. If the neutrinos have magnetic moments they can be effected by the large magnetic fields when they are 
passing through the magnetic region. Their spin can flip and the left-handed neutrino becomes a right-handed neutrino [9-12]. 
Thus the combine effect of the matter and the magnetic field called as spin flavor precession (SFP) can change left-handed electron 
neutrino to the right-handed another neutrino. This can also be responsible for the solar electron neutrino deficit. 
So far several studies related with the SFP have been studied in different aspects [13-18].
Astrophysical and cosmological arguments [19], Supernova 1987A [20], solar neutrino experiments looking neutrino-electron scattering [21] and
the reactor neutrino experiments [22, 23] provide some bounds on the neutrino magnetic moment. The new limit recently was obtained by GEMMA experiment: $\mu_{\nu}<2.9\times10^{-11}\mu_{B}$ at $90\%$ CL [24]. 
Detailed discussion on neutrino magnetic moment is also given elsewhere [25, 26]. 
In additon to the konowledge about neutrino magnetic moment, the thorough information of solar magnetic fields is needed for the SFP analysis in the Sun.
Even though the limited knowledge about it, some plausible profiles can be found in the literature [27, 28]. 
Standard solar model [28, 29] limits the solar magnetic field: $\sim$ 20 G near the solar surface [30], 20 kG - 300 kG at the convective zone [28] 
and $<  10^7 G $ at the solar center [28]. In this study the magnetic field profile is choosen as given in Ref. [27]. 
It has a peak at the bottom of the convective zone as shown in figure 1. 

Solar neutrinos can also be used for analysing of the physics beyond the Standard Model of the particle physics such as 
non-standard forward scattering [31], mass varrying neutrinos [32] and long-range leptonic forces [33]. 
The probe of non-standard neutrino interaction models is expected to observe in the transition region between 1 MeV and 4 MeV where 
the low energy solar neutrino experiments such as SNO+ will examine. Even though the data is poor in this region, the studies 
comparing the effects of non-standard models on the neutrino oscillation to the standard MSW-LMA oscillation shows that these effects 
modify the survival probability of neutrinos [31-35].  

In this letter, the combined effect of non-standard neutrino interactions (NSI) and SFP 
is examined in the case of two neutrino generations by assuming that the neutrinos are of Dirac type. 
The best fit LMA values are used for $\delta m^2_{12}$ and $\theta_{12}$ [36]. 
It is shown that the neutrino survival probability curves affected by SFP and NSI effects individually for some values of the parameters 
($\epsilon_{11}$, $\epsilon_{12}$ and $\mu B$) get close to the standard MSW curve when both effects are combined.
Therefore, one can say that the combined effect of them needs to be taken into account  when the solar electron neutrino 
data obtained by low energy solar neutrino experiments is investigated. 
Another analysis on the SFP effect in the presence of the NSI is examined for Majorana type solar neutrinos in Ref. [37].

\section{CONCLUSION}

\begin{figure}
[t]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[height=11cm,width=14cm]{figure2.eps}
\caption{Survival probabilities for MSW-LMA prediction alone (solid lines), SFP effect at different $\mu B$ values (dotted lines), 
NSI effect alone (dashed lines) and combined effect of the NSI and SFP effect (dotted-dashed lines).
Each column uses the same  $\epsilon_{11}$ and $\epsilon_{12}$ values, each row uses the same $\mu B$ values. } \label{fig:fig2}
\end{center}
\end{figure}

In this analysis it is assumed that the neutrinos are Dirac type and magnetic field profile given in figure 1 is of Gaussian shape extending over the entire Sun.
MSW-LMA best fit values are used in the calculations: $\delta m^2_{12}=7.54\times 10^{-5} eV^2$ and $sin^2\theta_{12}=0.308$ [36].
The combined effect of the non standard neutrino interaction and SFP on the survival probability of solar electron neutrinos is examined 
for various values of $\epsilon_{11}$, $\epsilon_{12}$ and $\mu B$. 
Electron neutrino survival probabilities plotted as a function of neutrino energy are shown in figure 2 for all stuations. 
Namely, while the solid, the dotted and the dashed lines represent the MSW-LMA prediction, SFP and NSI effect alone, respectively, the dotted-dashed lines represent the combined effect of the NSI and SFP in all graphes. 
As seen from the graphes, different from the SFP effect seen for all neutrino energies, the new physics effects changes the standard MSW curve especially at the energies of $E\gtrsim1$ MeV in which the region of $E\gtrsim3.5$ MeV is well examined by the solar neutrino experiments SNO and SK. 
It is seen that when the combined effect of the SFP and NSI is considered the curves for some values of the parameters ($\epsilon_{11}$, $\epsilon_{12}$ and $\mu B$) get closer to the standard curve than the curves affected by them individually.
Although stronge bounds on the NSI parameters have not been obtained yet, one can generalize this study for other values of $\epsilon_{11}$, $\epsilon_{12}$ [38]. 
The evidence of new physics is expected to observe  by the low energy solar neutrino experiments (in the range of $1 \text{MeV} \lesssim E \lesssim 4$ MeV) such as SNO+ experiment. 
Therefore, the stronger limits can be obtained from the new experiments and the neutrino phenomenology. 
As a conclusion, even though our knowledge about the solar magnetic field profile inside the Sun and the NSI parameters are not sufficient yet, 
as it is seen in figure 2 the combined effect of SFP and NSI needs to be taken into account when the solar electron neutrino data obtained by 
low energy solar neutrino experiments is investigated.
